column2: Explanation
in the command prompt, this will take you back one step
in the command prompt, this will take you to the folder
in the command prompt, this will show you all the folders inside the current folder
removes folder
makes a folder
lists current directories
clears prompt
creates new project. make everything lowercase
extra ruby code that we take into our project and use - performs one or more tasks
this stops the command prompt if it's stuck, stops server in the terminal/command prompt
sequel databse
in this folder, all the files that make up a rails project are saved here. This is where you do most of your work.
model view controller
each time you create a controller, it creates a helper, that's where you put extra code
this is where the yml files live
database
"rails server"
slash / localhost3000

column1: [in sublime text] circle next to tab (instead of x)
column2: this means that you have unsaved changes. You can hit ctrl + s to save
stands for embedded ruby. So we can embed ruby into our html file

column1: any time the command prompt has a little > carrot
column2: it's saying that the program is having errors and to run it again...ish
this is setting up a root to whatever page you specify. You can only have one root.
first, the hashtag is called an "action.' second, this is another way to tell the computer this is how you want to come to the page. But again, you can only have one root.
stores code
where you show your code
this is how you start to set up heroku. Basically it's saying that you can use squlite when you're developing it, but when you publish, you're going to use these gems to push it to heroku
if you ever make changes to gems, you have to go back to the command prompt and run bundle install to refresh the page
creates a git init - initiate repository
adds everything you've done the the repository you've initiated
After you've used the above to navigate to the correct folder, you would use this command code to run your program.
the string changes depending on what you've done
shows you the last thing you've done/typed in
this will create a new file
in Sublime text, this will search for the class/whatever you are cursored in and change all of them at the same time
document object model. All elements of whatever you create in your page. Your browser window comes with a bunch of other things that you can tap into.
makes a little ruby console that you can play around with
exits the irb

if you're in the command prompt, you've saved your program, and you've navigated to the correct directory, you can tell the command prompt ruby programname.rb
...and it will run the program!
comments out
indents left
indents right
will put the #{ } around it
this will check to see where you are in the git pushing process
When you have a Word File, you can either overwrite every saved file with a new save, or you have multiple versions. With Git, you don't have to. It keeps all your versions and never overwrites them.
a space where your projects live
this is the command that gives Git power. You basicaly take a "snapshot" of your repo at that point in time and gives you a checkpoint that you can evaluate

how do multiple people work on a project at the same time without Git getting them confused? Usually, they "branch off" the main project witht heir own versions full of changes they themselves have made. After they're done, they can merge that branch with the master.
initializes a new repo. Until you run this command, your directory is just a regular folder.
will tell you whether there is anything to commit (whether any changes have been made)
this does *not* add new files to your repo, but it kind of lines them up to ready them for a commit
most important command. this actually takes the snapshot for version control.
this will create a new branch, but it won't put you in it
it checks you IN to the branch you named

you go into the branch that you want to be the "main", and then you call git merge branchname (with the branch name you want to bring all the changes with). You have to merge both locally AND when you push
pushing from local git to github
if you're working on your local computer and want the most up-to-date version of your repo to work with, you would pull the changes fromo github
this will show you the last commit you made. just git log by itself will show the full list of commits
this blends together git add . and git commit -m . HOWEVER if you have made any new files, it will not commit them when you commit
will make a new branch and then navigate you to it as well. You need to be on the master branch (usually) when you call this command
calling this without a name will give you the full list and star the one you're currently on

takes all unsaved changes in modified files and stashes them to use later - git stash pop will take it back out

if you end up accidentally on the wrong branch, you can stash, change branch, and then stash pop
if you accidentally delete a file, this will bring the filename back for you!
will show which ways local iteration in Sublime differs from the most recently pushed branch
will find what you want in all folders of your project

if you're working in the group, one person will be in charge of the initial repo and making the project and everyone else will have to do this and then run rake db:migrate. If you want the same data, you would have to put it in the seed database

column2: pushing from git to heroku. When you first do this for each new project, there is a command or two that you'll have to run first
reverts the database to the last known state (usually that's undoing the most recent migration)
